articles.title: Composite Layer Aggregate Scores
articles.description: Data-informed decision making in the face of crisis.
articles.contents:
Contents
Computing Scores
Emergency Financial Support
Community Resiliency
Real-Time Fluctuations


Computing Scores
Once individual metric z-scores are all computed, the metrics can then be aggregated into a composite layer total z-score. Displayed here are maps showing, at the county and Census Tract levels, the aggregate z-scores for the three separate composite layers.
For additional reference information and guidance on z-scores, please refer to our Metric Standardization documentation.
Emergency Financial Support

Community Resiliency

Real-Time Fluctuations

articles.title: COVID-19 Composite Tool
articles.description: Data-informed decision making in the face of crisis.
articles.contents:
Welcome!

Welcome to our primary documentation site for our COVID Composite tool. Here you will find, hopefully, everything you should need to make sense of our COVID Composite tool and the associated metrics.
We also hope that those of you that are more technical will find that this open-source distribution will allow you to jump right in and play around.
Project License
Software licensed under the GNU General Public License v3.0
Information to Action Framework
If you are interested in integrating this tool into our broader Information to Action Framework, please check out our blog post here!
Composite Metrics & Visualizations
Community Resilience
Unemployment Rate
Poverty Rate
School Age Children Percent of Population
Percent of Population with Broadband Access
Percent of Population with Health Insurance Coverage
Percent of Population White Alone
Dependency Ratio
Emergency Financial Support
NC CRF County Per Capita Distributions
NC CRF Hospital Per Capita Distributions
HHS Uninsured Relief Fund Per Capita Distributions
HHS Rural Health Clinic Testing Fund Per Capita Distributions
HHS Provider Relief Fund Per Capita Distributions
HHS COVID-19 Awards Per Capita Distributions
Paycheck Protection Program Per Capita Distributions
Real-Time Fluctuations
Percent Change in Three Bedroom Home Values
Percent Change in Unemployment Rate
Percent Change in Taxable Sales
Percent Change in Sales Tax Distributable Proceeds
COVID-19 Cases Per 10,000 Residents
Unemployment Insurance Claimants Per 1,000 Residents

Community Resilience Composite
Emergency Financial Support Composite
Real-Time Fluctuations Composite

articles.title: Composite Reference
articles.description: Data-informed decision making in the face of crisis.

articles.title: Standardizing Metrics
articles.description: Data-informed decision making in the face of crisis.
articles.contents:
Contents
Z-Scores
Standardized Indicators
Community Resilience
Emergency Financial Support
Real-Time Fluctuations


Z-Scores
To not reinvent the wheel, below is a simple explanation of what a z-score is from the Investopedia website:

“A Z-score is a numerical measurement that describes a value’s relationship to the mean of a group of values. Z-score is measured in terms of standard deviations from the mean. If a Z-score is 0, it indicates that the data point’s score is identical to the mean score. A Z-score of 1.0 would indicate a value that is one standard deviation from the mean. Z-scores may be positive or negative, with a positive value indicating the score is above the mean and a negative score indicating it is below the mean.”1

Standardized Indicators
The composite layers and the composite in entirety, is about thinking through where the greatest chance for disproportionately negative impact might be. All composite z-scores are standardized so that a higher z-score equates to whatever direction we would consider, in the context of COVID-19, to be an indication of potential for disproportionate negative impact.
For a concrete example of this, the percent with health insurance coverage metric would normally result in a negative z-score to correspond with what would be considered negative. This is because z-score is just a measure of how many standard deviations away from the mean a value is. For census tracts with a low percentage of people having health insurance coverage, the z-score might be something like -2.5. To make everything easy to interpret here, that has been changed to 2.5 so that a higher z-score always indicates what we would consider not good in our composite.
So with that laid out, our composite metric assumptions for potentially disproportionate negative impact are:
Community Resilience
Unemployment Rate: higher
Poverty Rate: higher
School Age Children Percent of Population: higher
Percent of Population with Broadband Access: lower
Percent of Population with Health Insurance Coverage: lower
Percent of Population White Alone: lower
Dependency Ratio: higher
Emergency Financial Support
NC CRF County Per Capita Distributions: higher
NC CRF Hospital Per Capita Distributions: higher
HHS Uninsured Relief Fund Per Capita Distributions: higher
HHS Rural Health Clinic Testing Fund Per Capita Distributions: higher
HHS Provider Relief Fund Per Capita Distributions: higher
HHS COVID-19 Awards Per Capita Distributions: higher
Paycheck Protection Program Per Capita Distributions: higher
Real-Time Fluctuations
Percent Change in Three Bedroom Home Values: higher
Percent Change in Unemployment Rate: higher
Percent Change in Taxable Sales: higher
Percent Change in Sales Tax Distributable Proceeds: higher
COVID-19 Cases Per 10,000 Residents: higher
Unemployment Insurance Claimants Per 1,000 Residents: higher

https://www.investopedia.com/terms/z/zscore.asp↩︎
